entirely by a human.', 'document_classification': 'HUMAN_ONLY', 'version': '2025-01-09-base', 'language': 'en', 'pageNumber': 0, 'inputText': 'News Anchor and Reporter Diane is KITV4’s weekend evening anchor and weekday reporter. She hosts the Aging Well series on Tuesday evenings at 5, 6, and 10 p.m. She is a mother, a cat owner, and a yogi. New report on cycle of poverty in Hawaii urges state lawmakers to find solutions. HILO (ISLAND NEWS) -- A new report shows Hawaiʻi\'s lack of economic mobility imposes a high cost on us all, but especially on our keiki. The report found kids pay the biggest price with poorer health outcomes, less education, and lose out on future economic productivity. But there are ways to end this cycle of poverty. The report from Hawaii Appleseed Center says many families are one financial hardship away from slipping into poverty. Will White, deputy director of Hawai\'i Appleseed Center for Law & Economic Justice, says, "What we\'re looking to do is really highlight the high prevalence of lower wage, lower opportunity jobs available here in Hawaii and how those jobs just simply aren\'t enough to keep up with our cost of living." The report says Hawaii has the highest cost of living in America. Even though the minimum wage will be at $18 an hour by 2028, "$18 an hour is just not enough to make ends meet. For a single individual with no children, a living wage would be around $22 an hour," White notes. And if you have one child, you need to make over $41 an hour. But there\'s not a lot of jobs in Hawaii paying that, so "children who grow up in lower wage households have lower levels of educational attainment, they have lower health outcomes. And we even find they tend to make lower wages later on in life," continues White. White wants legislators to act now to ease the burden on working families "so they can afford to put food on the table and pay their rent at the end of the month- and hopefully not have to move to Vegas." The average Hawaii household spends over 40% of its budget on housing. White says one solution is to invest in affordable housing. Another is to create a state level child tax credit. Doing that "recognizes the extremely high costs associated with raising a family" Hawaii Appleseed Center will be working with lawmakers to push a bill like that this coming session. Do you have a story idea? Email news tips to news@kitv.com News Anchor and Reporter Diane is KITV4’s weekend evening anchor and weekday reporter. She hosts the Aging Well series on Tuesday evenings at 5, 6, and 10 p.m. She is a mother, a cat owner, and a yogi.
